Description: Reconstructed sherds of one side of neck of black figure painted pottery situla; design originally black, on drab ground, with incised lines; Gorgon (Medusa?) with curls and fringe of snakes (purple) with protruding tongues.
Curator's comments: Reconstructed with BM GR 1888,0208.41a & 1888,0208.13 (B106.9.1). CVA British Museum 8 Not from the same pot as Pl. GB 604, 13 (as Petrie and BMC have it). After the middle of the sixth century the East Greek Gorgon regularly has a loose halo of curling snakes. Examples from vase-painting are the Gorgoneia of a Fikellura cup in Samos (AM lix, Beilage 11. 1), of a Clazomenian sherd in Brussels (M.381: CVA iii, pl. 106. 5), and of a Clazomenian sarcophagus of markedly East Greek black figure style (see text to Pl. GB 614, 1). There are also many Gorgoneia of this type on East Greek coins (some references given by A. Furtwängler in W. H. Roscher's Ausführliches Lexikon der gr. und röm. Mythologie i. 2, 1717-18). On the situla the drawing is unusually slack.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B106.17)
CVA British Museum 8 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 13, British Museum 8 (Pl. GB 601, 6 (and Pl. GB 598, 1)) (Group C24)
Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (pl. xxvi, 10)
Weber 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus anderen ägyptischen Fundorten (TD 264)
